thread.title: In 14-2 win, Royals take game 4 of ALCS, up 3 games to 1
thread.title_full: In 14-2 win, Royals take game 4 of ALCS, up 3 games to 1

author: Laura McCallister
title: In 14-2 win, Royals take game 4 of ALCS, up 3 games to 1
text:
In 14-2 win, Royals take game 4 of ALCS, up 3 games to 1 - KCTV5 Member Center: In 14-2 win, Royals take game 4 of ALCS, up 3 games to 1 Posted: laura.mccallister@kctv5.com Kansas City Royals center fielder Lorenzo Cain warms up before Game 4 of baseball's American League Championship Series against the Toronto Blue Jays on Tuesday, Oct. 20, 2015, in Toronto. (AP Photo/Matt Slocum) Kansas City Royals' Lorenzo Cain scores past Toronto Blue Jays starting pitcher R.A. Dickey on a passed ball during the first inning in Game 4 of baseball's American League Championship Series on Tuesday, Oct. 20, 2015, in Toronto. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya) Kansas City Royals second baseman Ben Zobrist can's get a glove on a ground ball by Toronto Blue Jays' Ben Revere during the fifth inning in Game 4 of baseball's American League Championship Series on Tuesday, Oct. 20 in Toronto. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya) Kansas City Royals' Ben Zobrist celebrates in the dugout after scoring during the first inning in Game 4 of baseball's American League Championship Series against the Toronto Blue Jays on Tuesday, Oct. 20, 2015, in Toronto. (AP Photo/Matt Slocum) TORONTO (KCTV/AP) - 
The Kansas City Royals are now up three games to one in the American League Championship Series after Tuesday's 14-2 win over the Toronto Blue Jays. Ben Zobrist homered on a fly ball to right center field, bringing in himself and Alcides Escobar. The Kansas City Royals take an early 2-0 lead in the top of the 1st over the Toronto Blue Jays. 
The Blue Jays challenged a tag play call on the field was upheld. With Kendrys Morales batting, Lorenzo Cain scored. 
Mike Moustakas was out on a sacrifice fly to center field and Eric Hosmer scored. Royals up 4-0 in 1st. 
In the 2nd inning, Alex Rios hit a solo home run on a fly ball to center field and the Royals increased their lead 5-0. When Alcides Escobar was at bat, he got hit by a pitch. 
In the bottom of the 3rd, Blue Jays Josh Donaldson hit a ground-rule double on a line drive to left field and Ryan Goins scored. Royals now lead 5-1. Then, Blue Jays Jose Bautista grounded out and Ben Revere scored. Royals up 5-2. 
In the 4th inning, the Blue Jays challenged a tag play and the call on the field was overturned. Alex Rios was caught stealing second. 
Royals brought in pitcher Luke Hochevar to replace Chris Young in the 5th inning. 
In the seventh, the Royals loaded the bases off reliever LaTroy Hawkins. They chased him but Alcides Escobar's sacrifice fly made it 6-2. A wild pitch plated another run. 
Lorenzo Cain's single made it 8-2. Eric Hosmer's sacrifice made it 9-2. 
In the 8th inning, Escobar was out on a sacrifice fly to center field, allowing Salvador Perez to score. Royals lead 10-2. Then, Cain singled on a sharp ground ball to center field and Alex Gordon and Paulo Orlando scored. Royals lead 12-2. 
In the 9th inning, Escobar singled on a line drive to right field. Morales and Gordon scored. Royals lead 14-2. 
Previous Story: 
It's 59 degrees Fahrenheit and cloudy in Toronto but the roof is closed again. It was closed Monday night for Game 3 of the ALCS, too, even though it was 57 degrees at first pitch â€” that's 12 degrees warmer than it was for Game 2 at Citi Field in New York for the Mets-Cubs NLCS game on Sunday. 
"I was in New York on Saturday night and 12 degrees was not enough," Commissioner Rob Manfred said Tuesday. 
Major League baseball determines if the roof will be open or closed for postseason games, and Manfred was at Rogers Centre for Game 4. He said it was raining earlier on his way to the ballpark. 
"Why would you take a chance with a game this important. Now, whether it actually rains enough to interfere with play who knows but, again, when you have a roof why would you take a chance with it," he said. "My general thinking on things like this is things like this is that the individual clubs locally know best what should happen in their stadium." 
The Blue Jays were 38-14 with it open and 11-14 closed, and 4-0 with a combination of the two.
